title: Accelerate
author: Nicole Forsgren, Jez Humble, Gene Kim
description:
Describes the results of several years of research into high functioning teams.
                    The authors, present several metrics that correlate with high functioning teams
                    and the factors that contribute to these metrics. It is an excellent case for
                    devops and automation.

title: Artemis
author: Andy Weir
description:
A thrilling story set on the moon, where a young woman named Jazz Bashara gets
                    involved in a heist that could change the future of the lunar city, Artemis.

title: At the Edge of Time: Exploring the Mysteries of Our Universe’s First Seconds
author: Dan Hooper
description:
The first few trillionths of a second after the big bang was an incredibly
                    active and mysterious time in our universe. Dan Hooper explores these few
                    moments and explain how our universe may have come to be. He takes us to the
                    edge of our current understanding and surveys the various unanswered questions
                    that scientists are struggling with today.

title: Collapse
author: Jared Diamond
description: In Jared Diamond’s follow-up to the Pulitzer-Prize winning Guns, Germs and Steel, the author explores how climate change, the population explosion and political discord create the conditions for th...

title: Creation: Life and How to Make It
author: Steve Grand
description:
The presentation is excellent. Builds up the universe from the most fundamental
                    particle up to life and intelligence. Reframes our understanding of the physical
                    universe as well as what it means to be intelligent. I wish there was more
                    technical discussion on the implementation of the brain. However, the high level
                    ideas are quite useful and goes a long way towards helping you understand the
                    requirements for building truly intelligent life.

title: Death's End
author: Cixin Liu
description:
A satisfying end to the saga. Wraps up the story well and introduces some hope
                    which was a relief after the dark outlook of the previous book. Surprisingly,
                    was able to continue introducing new concepts and exploring intriguing ideas up
                    to the end.

title: Holly
author: Stephen King
description:
A well written mystery with good old fashioned human monsters. The detective
                    work unfolded smoothly. Some of the side quests felt forced but overall, did not
                    detract from the story.

title: How to Expect the Unexpected: The Science of Making Predictions―and the Art of Knowing When Not To
author: Kit Yates
description: This book was featured on the Physics World podcast.

title: Milton Berle's Private Joke File: Over 10,000 of His Best Gags, Anecdotes, and One-Liners
author: Milton berle

title: Now: The Physics of Time
author: Richard A. Muller
description:
This book explores the concept of time from a physics perspective. Richard A. Muller
                    delves into the nature of time, its relationship with space, and how it is perceived
                    by humans. The book provides a comprehensive understanding of time, combining
                    scientific theories with philosophical insights.

title: Project Hail Mary
author: Aandy Weir
description:
A well told science fiction story reminiscent of Heinlein. The main character is
                    a human who wakes up in a spaceship with no memory of how he got there. He must
                    figure out how to survive and find out what is going on.

title: Sleeping Beauties
author: Stephen King, Owen King
description: Easy flowing story telling. A gret premise and well executed.

title: The Age of Em: Work, Love and Life When Robots Rule the Earth
author: Robin Hanson
description: This is proving harder to read than I expected. I'm going to put it aside for now.

title: The Beginning of Infinity: Explanations That Transform the World
author: David Deutsch
description: This is proving harder to read than I expected. I'm going to put it aside for now.

title: The Blade Itself
author: Joe Abercrombie
description: The first novel in the First Law Trilogy and debut fantasy novel from New York Times bestseller, Joe Abercrombie. Logen Ninefingers, infamous barbarian, has finally run out of luck. Caught in one feud too many, he's on the verge of becoming a dead barbarian -- leaving nothing behind him but bad songs, dead friends, and a lot of happy enemies. Nobleman, dashing officer, and paragon of selfishness, Captain Jezal dan Luthar has nothing more dangerous in mind than fleecing his friends at cards and dreaming of glory in the fencing circle. But war is brewing, and on the battlefields of the frozen North they fight by altogether bloodier rules. Inquisitor Glokta, cripple turned torturer, would like nothing better than to see Jezal come home in a box. But then Glokta hates everyone: cutting treason out of the Union one confession at a time leaves little room for friendship. His latest trail of corpses may lead him right to the rotten heart of government, if he can stay alive long enough to follow it. Enter the wizard, Bayaz. A bald old man with a terrible temper and a pathetic assistant, he could be the First of the Magi, he could be a spectacular fraud, but whatever he is, he's about to make the lives of Logen, Jezal, and Glokta a whole lot more difficult. Murderous conspiracies rise to the surface, old scores are ready to be settled, and the line between hero and villain is sharp enough to draw blood. Unpredictable, compelling, wickedly funny, and packed with unforgettable characters, The Blade Itself is noir fantasy with a real cutting edge. First Law Trilogy The Blade Itself Before They Are Hanged Last Argument of Kings For more from Joe Abercrombie, check out: Novels in the First Law world Best Served Cold The Heroes Red Country

title: The Case Against Reality
author: Donald Hoffman
description:
This is a well-argued stance on reality and our perception of reality. The basic
                    concept is that we do not percieve the truth of reality, rather, we percieve
                    reality in the way that maximises our chance of survival. The argument is that
                    we create a reality when we observe the world. That reality that we create may
                    not be the objective reality.

title: The Dark Forest
author: Cixin Liu
description:
A bit dark. Proposes a bleak outlook on the relationship between civilizations
                    in the universe. Incredibly well written.

title: The Far Side Gallery
author: Gary Larson
description:
I deliberately paced myself with this one. I limited myself to 2 pages per
                    night.

title: The Math of Life and Death: 7 Mathematical Principles That Shape Our Lives
author: Kit Yates

title: The Quest for Eden
author: Elena Maria Marsella
description:
An interesting exploration of the stories that we tell through the eyes of an Anthropologist. Re-interprets the myths of the past with new light.

I'm probably not going to complete this book. It is brilliantly written and quite compelling but the last few chapters feel like a chore.

title: The Three-Body Problem
author: Cixin Liu
description:
Profound is an understatment. This well told story introduced many unique
                    concepts. Intelligent use of scientific knowledge.

title: The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, 2nd Ed.
author: Edward R. Tufte

title: We Have No Idea: A Guide to the Unknown Universe
author: Jorge Cham, Daniel Whiteson
